WILLIAMS: No, no, no. That's not what they're saying. They're saying -- she's saying that she wants to eliminate his demand that it be freezing. And he has said he likes a cold environment.

KILMEADE: In the past, but the thing is, it's like boxing, Juan.

BRUCE: And she wants it at 76.

KILMEADE: You're a boxing fan. If you're the champion, you get to pick the ring, the venue.

WILLIAMS: That's what she said. She said CBS, the local CBS, the affiliate here in New York, negotiated exclusively with him. Because she wanted several debates. She's only getting one debate on his terms.

BRUCE: Because he's -- he's leading. And he doesn't even really need to do it, because he's ahead. But thank you for man-splaining that for me.

Yes, I mean, this is -- this is what you're going to see, and this is what we want. I want women to run for office, but we don't want it to all be about sexism.

PERINO: I do want it to be comfortable in the room.

BRUCE: But 76 isn't even comfortable. Right? I mean, she's asking --

PERINO: No, see it depends. Like, at 75, I'm cold. At 76, I'm hot. So it's, like, 75.5 would be perfect.

GUTFELD: Do you want to talk about sexism, though? Think about all of the men who built buildings, who built the buildings that people actually use, who risked their lives on girders in the 1960s and the 1970s, who built the bridges.

KILMEADE: And then blew the money on the track.

GUTFELD: Or if the -- oh, no, they fell.

KILMEADE: They fell.

GUTFELD: Brooklyn Bridge, look at the numbers of people who died on the Brooklyn Bridge.

BRUCE: All the men who made things possible and now women can help make them possible, too.

GUTFELD: There you go.

BRUCE: Coming up, "One More Thing" is coming up next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

GUTFELD: "OMT" -- Juan.

WILLIAMS: Well, Gregory, you know what? Dreams do come true.

GUTFELD: No, they don't.

WILLIAMS: And sometimes in doubles. Yes, because that's what happened for Sophia Sanchez, an 11-year-old awaiting a heart transplant in Chicago. She posted a video of her dancing in the hospital with an I.V. in her arm to rapper Drake's "In My Feelings." So then she asked Drake to come visit her. Against all odds, guess what happened? He did.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SOPHIA SANCHEZ, HEART TRANSPLANT PATIENT: Oh, my God!

DRAKE, RAP ARTIST: You asked me to come, I'm here. What's up?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIAMS: Sophia -- Sophia also asked -- and this is the double, Gregory - - Sophia asked for a new heart, because she was struggling. And guess what? The second dream also came true.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: You're getting a heart.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Congratulations.

SANCHEZ: I'm getting a heart, Mom!

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIAMS: Oh, my gosh. So yesterday, Sophia had the heart implanted and, according to her mom, Natalie, Sophia is doing well. I want you to know, Sophia, you've got five people here at FOX rooting and praying for you.

PERINO: Like, 500 million.

WILLIAMS: Really.

GUTFELD: You have proven me wrong, Juan.

WILLIAMS: Wow. What?

GUTFELD: Now I need to find a heart. All right.

PERINO: No one's going to give you a heart.

GUTFELD: No one's going to give me a heart.

KILMEADE: Especially after this.

GRAPHIC: Greg's Brian Kilmeade Spelling News

GUTFELD: "Greg's Brian Kilmeade Spelling News." Got a lot of big news in the Brian Kilmeade spelling arena. Let's go live to tape.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LARRY KUDLOW, CHIEF WHITE HOUSE ECONOMIC ADVISOR: There's a word that Canada has trouble with. It's M-I-L-K.

KILMEADE: Now, in terms of Canada, I guess Canada hates milk. I mean, hates to talk about milk, M-A-L-K.

STEVE DOOCY, CO-HOST, "FOX & FRIENDS": They're lactose intolerant.

KILMEADE: That's what you've got.

DOOCY: By the way, Brian -- Brian, did you say -- it's "M-I-L-K".

KILMEADE: You're right. Thank you very much.

DOOCY: Not "M-A-L-K."

KILMEADE: You're -- thanks for correcting me. You helped me, saved a headline. Appreciate it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

GUTFELD: How nice of Larry to correct you on television.

KILMEADE: That would have slipped by the Gutfeld staff, except for Larry corrected me.

PERINO: I thought I heard you say "I" in my -- OK, you didn't.

KILMEADE: I know how to spell "milk," just not in the morning.

GUTFELD: Dana.

WILLIAMS: How about "potato"?

PERINO: I have something to promote. I'm going to be on Tucker Carlson tonight at 8 p.m., so you can check that out there. We have a graphic. Yes, I have a graphic today.

Marie Unanue, she has a new book. She's a friend of mine. And it is called "The Adventures of Phatty and Payaso: Central Park," ad it's a children's book, a chapter book, actually. So if you are a little more advanced, you might like it. Phatty and Payaso, they go to Central Park. They want to go take a stand against bullying, but then they get -- all sorts of adventures. They have a LetsBeKind.com adventure that goes with it, if you want to check it out.

GUTFELD: Brian.

KILMEADE: Real quick, my paperback of "Andrew Jackson: Miracle of New Orleans," includes what other presidents thought of Andrew Jackson, because he's so controversial today. It's coming out in October. And I'm going to couple it with three events. One in Tampa, one in Norfolk, one in Nashville. His BrianKilmeade.com.

I want to talk about George Washington, Thomas Jefferson and the Tripoli pirates, as well as "Andrew Jackson: Miracle of New Orleans." "America Great from the Start." Because so many people have problems with our history, I wanted to have a live event where people can ask questions.

GUTFELD: Excellent, brain. Tammy.

BRUCE: And for everyone's books and events, you can now get a pumpkin spice latte. I know fall does not start until the 22, but already the pumpkin spice latte is out. It is their biggest selling drink of all time.

GUTFELD: I love it. I love it.

BRUCE: I -- I love it as well.

PERINO: You do?

BRUE: Normally, I like regular coffee but in this case, that's for me --

PERINO: In 95 degree heat?

BRUCE: In season, sure.

KILMEADE: But they use real pumpkin.

BRUCE: They use real pumpkin, and you can get a pumpkin scones. You can get, like, a cookie in the shape of an owl that's a pumpkin. So welcome to fall, and enjoy the pumpkin spice latte.

GUTFELD: All right. Set your DVRs. Never miss an episode of THE FIVE. "SPECIAL REPORT" up next. Hey, Bret.

BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: Greg, thanks. Welcome to a very hot White House North Lawn.

END

urn:contentItem:5XBR-4721-JCMN-Y25X-00000-00Coinbase UK CEO: 'We Need Centralized Entities Supporting Crypto'2019-10-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:35:13ZLexisNexisCoinbase UK CEO: 'We Need Centralized Entities Supporting Crypto'Stefan

Oct 24, 2019( DC Forecasts: https://www.dcforecasts.com Delivered by Newstex)   https://www.dcforecasts.com/advertise/ The latest Coinbase news[1] bring the head of the United Kingdom brach named Zeeshan Feroz, arguing that the world needs centralized entities that support cryptocurrency. The Coinbase UK CEO noted that entities like central banks and Facebook are more than needed for overall support of the entire crypto ecosystem.

In an interview that Feroz had with CNBC published on October 24[2], he said that there are two ways for cryptocurrency to go mainstream. One of them is the central bank digital currency (CBDC) issuance and the other is Facebook's Libra stablecoin which is expected to launch in 2020. As distinct from cryptocurrencies as possible, a CBDC is a digital currency that is issued by a central bank. The point of the Coinbase UK CEO with a currency like this is to exploit its legal tender status that depends on government regulation or law. CBDCs such as the digital US dollar or British pound, according to Feroz, could 'catalyze adoption in a way that us geeks in Silicon Valley might not be able to.' Aside from this, Feroz did not mention the only CBDC that has been announced by a major global economy to date: the People's Bank of China and its digital renminbi. As he continued, another route to mass adoption would be through Facebook and 'with the billions of users that they have.' The Coinbase UK CEO was in the Libra coin news[3] for stating the following: 'Libra as a currency has the potential to be a form of payment that is really universal in its nature. It's not going to be easy, you're really challenging the status quo. We're at step one of a thousand step journey.' Coinbase is one of the 21 remaining companies that are part of the Libra Association, which is an organization known for being under scrutiny by lawmakers across the world and consequently losing seven high-profile participants such as Visa, eBay and Mastercard.[4] The Coinbase UK CEO also argued that at the end of the long journey with Libra, we could be poised to establish 'a financial system that is more open, where people can send funds globally as easily as you send an email.' When talking about central entities, Feroz pointed out to a place for centralized businesses where they would support the cryptosystem. 'To transition from the world we're in today to that utopia, perhaps you need centralized entities, you need an on and off-ramp. You can't buy crypto if you don't have a centralized business that can maintain those relationships with banks,' the Coinbase UK CEO concluded. The post Coinbase UK CEO: 'We Need Centralized Entities Supporting Crypto'[5] appeared first on DC Forecasts - Leading Digital Currencies[6]. [ 1]: http://www.dcforecasts.com/coinbase-news/ [ 2]:   https://www.cnbc.com/video/2019/10/24/central-banks-and-big-tech-can-take-crypto-mainstream-coinbase-ceo.html [ 3]:   http://www.dcforecasts.com/libra-coin-news/ [ 4]:   http://www.dcforecasts.com/libra-coin-news/libra-suffers-heavy-blows-visa-ebay-and-mastercard-quit/ [ 5]:   https://www.dcforecasts.com/coinbase-news/coinbase-uk-ceo-we-need-centralized-entities-supporting-crypto/ [ 6]:   https://www.dcforecasts.com

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y33-4101-DY2T-61XF-00000-00Colby Cosh: The Liberals' war on social media is meant to end in victory ... of a kind2019-06-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:35:11ZLexisNexisFULL COMMENTColby Cosh: The Liberals' war on social media is meant to end in victory ... of a kind

The federal Liberals' war on social media opened a new front in the foyer of the West Block on Thursday as Democratic Institutions Minister Karina Gould denounced Twitter for its continuing silence on her "Declaration on Electoral Integrity."( https://www.canada.ca/en/democratic-institutions/services/protecting-democracy/declaration-electoral-integrity.html ) The D.I.M. issued the Declaration last week; it's a mushy motherhood statement, co-signed so far by Facebook, Google and Microsoft, in which a) the social media and advertising platforms mostly agree to do the stuff they're already doing to try to remain in general good public odour and b) the Canadian government agrees to approve of this.

Twitter has been reluctant to sign up, even though issuing a "Declaration" is an obvious sign on the part of the government that its ability to tailor social media by means of statute and regulation has already reached something of a practical limit. Gould's Bill C-76, passed in December and intended to apply to the upcoming federal election, created new regulations for third-party political advertisers on electronic platforms. This had an immediate comic effect, as anybody knows if they watched Google representatives being harangued at the Commons Access to Information, Privacy and Ethics Committee on May 9.

Google was hauled before the committee because it couldn't figure out a way to comply with C-76's requirements in time for the election. As Colin McKay and Jason Kee tried to explain to the vexed legislators, Google is in the business of serving unfathomable mass quantities of advertising to other people's websites and phone applications and keeping some of the cash. They don't make either the ads or the sites to which they're served: they are, for this purpose, a pipeline company that imposes a lucrative toll. Like other platforms they are busily trying to stamp out the most socially obnoxious and unethical content in the pipeline, with varying amounts of success: a screening algorithm that gets invented on January 1st is bound to be gamed before sunrise January 2nd.

In other words, it's a technological arms race. But some of the specifics of C-76's rules on political advertising presented immediate and difficult problems for Google, and it did its best to explain them to the committee. The law, as passed, imposes "registry" requirements on the sites and apps connected to the pipeline, who may not even know what ads they are showing. And the registry, if it could be created by Google for its customers, would have to be updated daily. "This effectively means," observed Google lawyer Jason Kee, "that the registry must be updated in real time, as a regulated political ad that was displayed at 11:59 p.m. would need to be included in the registry before midnight."

Not feasible, said Kee, at least on such short notice. Finally, the broad definition of "election advertising" written into the law was a problem: it includes any ad "taking a position on an issue with which a registered party or candidate is associated," which might literally change from minute to minute during a campaign. What's the technological solution to that? (Even if Google could hire a billion human editors to do that work, could the company be sure of complying with C-76?)

So Google, the accused social poisoner and wrecker of democracy, decided to obey the law by cancelling all political ad sales in Canada during the upcoming regulated period. You might suppose that they would be thanked for withdrawing the poison at their own undoubtedly significant expense. Instead, the Liberals, like the restaurant patron who complains that the food is lousy and the portions are so small, flew into a genuine rage. Nathaniel Erskine-Smith whined that "We are too small for you ... You are too important, and we are just not important enough for Google to take us seriously."

Colby Cosh: 'Double intense' casualties - a glance beyond the beaches of D-Day( https://nationalpost.com/opinion/colby-cosh-double-intense-casualties-a-glance-beyond-the-beaches-of-d-day )

Colby Cosh: You may not have noticed, but reproductive freedom is growing( https://nationalpost.com/opinion/colby-cosh-you-may-not-have-noticed-but-reproductive-freedom-is-growing )

Colby Cosh: Japan hates when we flip its PM's name around, but Japan doesn't get to decide( https://nationalpost.com/opinion/colby-cosh-yes-japan-fine-but-what-about-the-hungarians )

Erskine-Smith and other committee members demanded to know exactly how soon Google would be bringing political ads back to Canada, furiously trying to pin down a 2023 date. In the video of the meeting they seem quite desperate about this - as one might expect from representatives of a technologically aware major political party, one with well-developed demographic targets that can really only be attacked with Google's help. If you read the transcript( https://www.ourcommons.ca/DocumentViewer/en/42-1/ETHI/meeting-148/evidence ) of the meeting, or better yet view Erskine-Smith's cranky demeanour in the archived video, you will understand that the Liberal dialogue with big tech really has the goal of being seen to do something about social media and online advertising without flustering the golden goose.

Which makes Karina Gould's tantrum in the foyer even funnier. Having treated Google peevishly for taking the Atlas Shrugged approach to C-76, the government was suddenly upholding it as the ultimate good citizen for the purpose of castigating Twitter, a platform "(We) know ... has been used and manipulated by foreign and malicious actors." Increasingly, when politicians discuss social media, they seem to be advancing the premise that we can only preserve an open, free and internationalist society as long as someone will agree to keep all those devious and unclean outsiders off our internet. (Our own privilege as Canadians of hopping on Twitter and hurling memes and insults at the Saudis or the Israelis or the Russians or the Americans, of course, is never to be questioned.)

National Post

urn:contentItem:5W90-JSC1-F125-10T4-00000-00Colby Cosh: The Liberals' war on social media is meant to end in victory ... of a kind2019-06-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:35:11ZLexisNexisFULL COMMENTColby Cosh: The Liberals' war on social media is meant to end in victory ... of a kind

The federal Liberals' war on social media opened a new front in the foyer of the West Block on Thursday as Democratic Institutions Minister Karina Gould denounced Twitter for its continuing silence on her "Declaration on Electoral Integrity."( https://www.canada.ca/en/democratic-institutions/services/protecting-democracy/declaration-electoral-integrity.html ) The D.I.M. issued the Declaration last week; it's a mushy motherhood statement, co-signed so far by Facebook, Google and Microsoft, in which a) the social media and advertising platforms mostly agree to do the stuff they're already doing to try to remain in general good public odour and b) the Canadian government agrees to approve of this.

Twitter has been reluctant to sign up, even though issuing a "Declaration" is an obvious sign on the part of the government that its ability to tailor social media by means of statute and regulation has already reached something of a practical limit. Gould's Bill C-76, passed in December and intended to apply to the upcoming federal election, created new regulations for third-party political advertisers on electronic platforms. This had an immediate comic effect, as anybody knows if they watched Google representatives being harangued at the Commons Access to Information, Privacy and Ethics Committee on May 9.

Google was hauled before the committee because it couldn't figure out a way to comply with C-76's requirements in time for the election. As Colin McKay and Jason Kee tried to explain to the vexed legislators, Google is in the business of serving unfathomable mass quantities of advertising to other people's websites and phone applications and keeping some of the cash. They don't make either the ads or the sites to which they're served: they are, for this purpose, a pipeline company that imposes a lucrative toll. Like other platforms they are busily trying to stamp out the most socially obnoxious and unethical content in the pipeline, with varying amounts of success: a screening algorithm that gets invented on January 1st is bound to be gamed before sunrise January 2nd.

In other words, it's a technological arms race. But some of the specifics of C-76's rules on political advertising presented immediate and difficult problems for Google, and it did its best to explain them to the committee. The law, as passed, imposes "registry" requirements on the sites and apps connected to the pipeline, who may not even know what ads they are showing. And the registry, if it could be created by Google for its customers, would have to be updated daily. "This effectively means," observed Google lawyer Jason Kee, "that the registry must be updated in real time, as a regulated political ad that was displayed at 11:59 p.m. would need to be included in the registry before midnight."

Not feasible, said Kee, at least on such short notice. Finally, the broad definition of "election advertising" written into the law was a problem: it includes any ad "taking a position on an issue with which a registered party or candidate is associated," which might literally change from minute to minute during a campaign. What's the technological solution to that? (Even if Google could hire a billion human editors to do that work, could the company be sure of complying with C-76?)

So Google, the accused social poisoner and wrecker of democracy, decided to obey the law by cancelling all political ad sales in Canada during the upcoming regulated period. You might suppose that they would be thanked for withdrawing the poison at their own undoubtedly significant expense. Instead, the Liberals, like the restaurant patron who complains that the food is lousy and the portions are so small, flew into a genuine rage. Nathaniel Erskine-Smith whined that "We are too small for you ... You are too important, and we are just not important enough for Google to take us seriously."

Colby Cosh: 'Double intense' casualties - a glance beyond the beaches of D-Day( https://nationalpost.com/opinion/colby-cosh-double-intense-casualties-a-glance-beyond-the-beaches-of-d-day )

Colby Cosh: You may not have noticed, but reproductive freedom is growing( https://nationalpost.com/opinion/colby-cosh-you-may-not-have-noticed-but-reproductive-freedom-is-growing )

Colby Cosh: Japan hates when we flip its PM's name around, but Japan doesn't get to decide( https://nationalpost.com/opinion/colby-cosh-yes-japan-fine-but-what-about-the-hungarians )

Erskine-Smith and other committee members demanded to know exactly how soon Google would be bringing political ads back to Canada, furiously trying to pin down a 2023 date. In the video of the meeting they seem quite desperate about this - as one might expect from representatives of a technologically aware major political party, one with well-developed demographic targets that can really only be attacked with Google's help. If you read the transcript( https://www.ourcommons.ca/DocumentViewer/en/42-1/ETHI/meeting-148/evidence ) of the meeting, or better yet view Erskine-Smith's cranky demeanour in the archived video, you will understand that the Liberal dialogue with big tech really has the goal of being seen to do something about social media and online advertising without flustering the golden goose.

Which makes Karina Gould's tantrum in the foyer even funnier. Having treated Google peevishly for taking the Atlas Shrugged approach to C-76, the government was suddenly upholding it as the ultimate good citizen for the purpose of castigating Twitter, a platform "(We) know ... has been used and manipulated by foreign and malicious actors." Increasingly, when politicians discuss social media, they seem to be advancing the premise that we can only preserve an open, free and internationalist society as long as someone will agree to keep all those devious and unclean outsiders off our internet. (Our own privilege as Canadians of hopping on Twitter and hurling memes and insults at the Saudis or the Israelis or the Russians or the Americans, of course, is never to be questioned.)

National Post

urn:contentItem:5WR2-9MF1-DYTY-C3FX-00000-00Cold, hard logic of Washington politics dampens hopes for a UK-US trade deal;Roadblocks stand in the way of efforts by Johnson's team to drive forward a 'turbo-charged' process2019-08-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:35:11ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Cold, hard logic of Washington politics dampens hopes for a UK-US trade dealRoadblocks stand in the way of efforts by Johnson's team to drive forward a 'turbo-charged' processBen Riley-Smith

WHEN Donald Trump was musing in private about a Boris Johnson premiership last month one thing became clear to those listening: he would be with his new counterpart all the way on Brexit.

Deal or no deal come Oct 31, the US president would stand by his "friend". "His position is to support Boris and sustain Boris," said a source close to the White House who heard the remarks.

Amid the transatlantic back-slapping, hopes for a UK-US free trade deal - one that could be done quickly as a symbol of Britain's post-EU future - have re-entered the spotlight.

Liz Truss, the new International Trade Secretary, named the deal her "number one priority" and met Woody Johnson, America's UK ambassador, within days of taking the job.

Boris Johnson and Mr Trump discussed the topic on their first phone call as joint world leaders and promised to "immediately deepen and expand" their nations' trade relationship when Brexit is done.

The message has been heard loud and clear by British diplomats too, who are now seeking to turn calls for a "turbo-charged" process into a reality without breaking rules about not starting formal negotiations.

And yet, according to more than a dozen figures tapped into early talks, little has changed in the nuts and bolts.

The cold hard logic of Washington politics remains.

Liam Fox, dismissed as international trade secretary last week after three years, had that hammered home to him during a Washington trip last month, In a meeting with Ron Wyden, the most senior Democrat on the Senate finance committee, Mr Fox was given something between a warning and a threat.

"There should not be any negotiations on a trade deal as long as as a digital services tax is being pursued by Britain," Mr Wyden told Mr Fox, or words to that effect. During the same trip an identical message was delivered by Chuck Grassley, the committee's top Republican senator.

Such remarks have underscored what British officials now see as a significant threat to the hopes of speedy trade deal. The policy in question, a 2 per cent tax on UK revenues for big tech companies, is due to become law in this autumn's budget.

There are also persistent murmurs about the UK's preparedness to launch into full scale negotiations on Nov 1. Much of the hold-up is unavoidable, as Britain's trade relationship with the US depends on its trade relationship with the EU post-Brexit.

In other areas there is more culpability. America has published its trade deal priorities, some 5,000 words of "summary" targets, and held public hearings about them. Britain has done neither.

One figure in a US business body being kept abreast with talks doubted the quality of the UK's negotiators. "They have not done trade deal negotiations for 46 years," the source said, referring to the date Britain joined the European Economic Community. "I don't really know if they can do it. This is a new game for them."

Some Republicans are lobbying for a deal to be done in 2020, seeing it as triple-whammy: strengthen relations with Britain, help American firms and hand Mr Trump a win he can sell before the Nov 2020 election.

It is not impossible. America struck a trade deal with South Korea after around a year of negotiations.

Other potential pitfalls include the Brexit date being pushed back and the Democrats, who hold a majority in the House of Representatives, refusing to vote any deal through.

Furthermore, Mr Trump has only 15 months left in his first term - and even in trade, the UK deal is at best third on his priority list, behind passing his renegotiated North American Free Trade Agreement and resolving the confrontation with China.

Then there are the talks themselves. Britain has already been hit with tariffs once by the Trump administration, affecting steel exports to the US.

One ex-cabinet member dismissed in Mr Johnson's "Night of the Blond Knives'" believes a face-saving agreement could be struck next year, perhaps around regulations - but the chances of completing a meaningful trade deal by the end of 2020 were close to zero. By then Mr Trump, along with his burgeoning relationship with Mr Johnson, could be political history.

Front Bench Everything you need to know from Westminster, every weekday morning www.telegraph.co.uk/ front-bench

urn:contentItem:5M6J-R1S1-JDPT-T0M3-00000-00COLE SMEAD, MANAGING DIRECTOR AND PORTFOLIO MANAGER, SMEAD CAPITAL MANAGEMENT, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TELEVISION2016-11-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:35:11ZLexisNexisCOLE SMEAD, MANAGING DIRECTOR AND PORTFOLIO MANAGER, SMEAD CAPITAL MANAGEMENT, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TELEVISION

November 17, 2016

NEWS PROGRAM

COLE SMEAD, MANAGING DIRECTOR AND PORTFOLIO MANAGER, SMEAD CAPITAL MANAGEMENT,

EDWARDS: Let's welcome to the program, Cole Smead, managing director and portfolio manager at Smead Capital Management. He's in town, joins us here in London. Cole, great to see you this morning. We just ran through a whole host of opinions from the Fed and lots to watch on the Fed story at the moment. The truth is though, that we don't really know very much about what President-elect Trump will do in terms of fiscal policy. We know a bit about what he intends, what he actually manages to get support for on Capitol Hill is another question.

SMEAD: Correct. He has moved the bond market a major way from a sentiment standpoint. The -- the oddity is, the things that are likely to move inflation the most which would be the borrowing of money by U.S. households has not been going on. So if people are worried about fiscal policy, in the first couple days post reaction to election, there has not been a major move in housing stocks which would be the primary way that households borrow money, create a lot more money in the money supply, and it goes to work in the economy. So you know, there were certain industries, financials, obviously, health care that were -- have strong political fears, at the same time, what could go on the next five years regardless of Hillary or Donald, it -- it looks very good.

GAMAL EL-DIN: Speaking of inflation, we're looking ahead to a tips auction in the U.S. Again, no-brainer to -- to buy into that, but that's also going to be a verdict as to whether the reflation train is on, right?

SMEAD: Sure. Well, people are talking about inflation, this idea of real growth is missing, OK? It -- a potent cocktail would not only be inflation that's actually present which is now a conversation, but real growth that kicks in as well. That cocktail could kill the bond market which just this initial move has been very tumultuous. (inaudible) as you point out, the spread between the German yield and the U.S. yield, it's wide. It's very unlikely the largest economy in the world will pay higher rates and others won't have to follow suit just like the regulations on banks, et cetera.

EDWARDS: So you think this -- you think this -- you think that the -- the -- I mean, that's why see the BOJ active in the markets today because -- because of the way that Donald Trump' election victory has moved bond markets not just in the U.S., but globally. So you don't think then that the infrastructure spending that we're hearing Donald Trump talk about in -- with scant details so far, but certainly, that's one theme. You don't think that's going to be enough to materially move U.S. growth?

SMEAD: No. In terms of expectations, it's moved some expectations, but actually moving the needle, our economy's way bigger tied to consumers. One other thing I'll mention. Think about -- you know, we got 35 percent corporate tax rates in the United States of America. Well, other places have 15. Did that stop U.S. companies from fining 15 percent tax rates? Not at all. So this arbitrage at what goes on in the U.S. versus outside the borders is always going to be the free market deciding what they want to do with their money in time.

GAMAL EL-DIN: We're waiting for more details on policy from Donald Trump and his incoming administration. How do investors position themselves to make sure that they come out on the right side of this trade.

SMEAD: Sure. Sure. Great question. Well, the two things that I've been excited about this year and were considered probably politically palatable in --in the -- prior to the election were tech, momentum growth, and secondly, the safety trade. In other words, if yields are going to stay down forever, why not lengthen your duration in bond surrogates and long-duration tech plays? Well, those things have woken up to a change in sentiment. Just in the last, you know, call it week, it's been a market change. So, you know, the big tech companies are down pretty nicely since the election, and secondly, the bond surrogates are getting pounded with the bond market at the same time. What's going to produce earnings growth and free cash flow growth is what investors might wake up to the next five years, and in the U.S. stock market, that could be a tumultuous thing because half the revenues come from abroad. So what goes on in our border might not be helpful to the index per se.

EDWARDS: So -- so from what you're saying then, and I know you're a big stock picking and it's been a tough time to be a stock picker because of some of these big global themes, but you think stock picking now is warranted because of the threats to the tech sectors, the -- the threats to some of those bond proxy trade.

SMEAD: Sure. It's just not a broad opportunity in U.S. equities. Let me give you an example. They call it 17 times earnings multiple on the on the S&P 500. It's no outlandish, nowhere near 99 just to give , you know, European investors sense, but it -- it's more expensive than history. Small caps are more expensive and they have snapped a 10 plus percent in the week following the election, so I highlight that because, OK, do you want to pay 200 times earnings for the market cap in the S&P 500 index, you can out all the home builders that we just talked about inside, all the publicly traded ones inside the market cap of Accenture, OK? So what if things go on in the U.S. economy that benefit certain industries because their economics are good not because of political reasons, and what if the index doesn't own enough?

EDWARDS: So which sectors are you buying then, with that in mind?

We --we own a lot of discretionary -- we continue to buy new names, it would be like Scripps Network Interactive, Home -- Home and Garden Television, Food Channel, Travel Channel, they're very millennial as subjects, but a lot of these millennials haven't bought houses yet, so very directly tied to advertisers. The financials look good, home mortgage originations. It's not about rates. Rates will help all financial institutions here, you know, in -- in the U.K. as well, but at the same time, it really comes out of who's going to be underwriting mortgages that unlocks the inflation, the growth, the incomes, et cetera.

GAMAL EL-DIN: You mentioned financials. There was a theme as well among investors the last week that Trumps going to tear up regulation, he's going to make it a lot easier for banks to make more money. Is that -- is that something that you -- you've penciled in as well?

SMEAD: Overnight, no. At the same time, you know, this is not a change in -- in U.S. politics in a way that's going to be catastrophic, it will just marginally go to businesses and say, "Hey, what do you need to do to grow your business," because the economics was the most important equation in the U.S. election. That's what people want, so they're going to look for ways to allow business to go do -- do what they do. I'll give you a quick example. Fox Broadcasting two days after the election filed a suit with the SEC to be able to go above a 40 percent restriction in owning their affiliates across the United States, why? Because if Google can have 65 percent market share, why can't a broadcasting station own more than 40 percent of the national market? It's just -- it's but it's a difference in what was the political regime prior versus what's the political regime after.

EDWARDS: Cole, thank you very much for coming on (inaudible) this morning. Cole Smead, the managing director and portfolio manager at Smead Capital Management.

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

Despite the challenges, the COVID-19 pandemic and resulting recession drives many businesses to accelerate innovation in their operating model...

Despite the challenges, the COVID-19 pandemic and resulting recession drives many businesses to accelerate innovation in their operating model and find ways to create differentiated value. Is your company looking for new avenues to create value, grow reven...

Despite the challenges, the COVID-19 pandemic and resulting recession drives many businesses to accelerate innovation in their operating model and find ways to create differentiated value. Is your company looking for new avenues to create value, grow revenue, build resilience and optimize processes? If so, you should pay attention to why leading companies now invest in blockchain technology to build powerful, secure networks that enable collaborative value creation among multiple businesses and even among industries. As I explained in my prior blog, blockchain technology eliminates the constraints of current software systems such as ERP applications that rely on database technologies with walled access to data, such as the following: Unacceptable friction and cost in trying to gain access to entities’ data and maintain transparency Lack of trust Lack of a single source of truth These constraints inhibit building networks for collaborative ecosystems. However, the market now has huge interest in companies assisting organizations to eliminate these constraints by using blockchain. Its distributed-ledger technology supports building specialized networks that allow collaboration across ecosystems. At Everest Group, we refer to these networks built on a blockchain foundation as Network Resource Planner (NRP) solutions. The primary benefit of these solutions is that they build trust among all the ecosystem participants; therefore, they enable and support transparency and data sharing. A lot of processes and transactions go back and forth in an ecosystem, but if the supporting technology uses ERP-based architecture, all participants keep their accounts and data separate and private. Consequently, they lack a shared world view, a shared understanding of customers, so they cannot collaborate to create new shared value. This closed, inflexible structure does not work in today’s reality of needing to collaborate across internal or external boundaries that prevent data access. Your company – along with other businesses and industries – can gain true value by using software that reimagines the boundaries of each workflow in a shared network used by varied trusted stakeholders. Major players investing in technology that enables NRP solutions Blockchain, the fundamental platform for building Network Resource Planner solutions, successfully went through rigorous testing worldwide over the past few years. It proved to be a highly secure and scalable architecture with a solid foundation. In the market today, major players such as big tech firms, large global financial institutions and governments worldwide invest in the foundational architecture to extend its capabilities. NRP examples The benefits of a Network Resource Planner solution are twofold – process optimization and new revenue-stream creation. Consider, for instance, an NPR solution for manufacturing companies to use in tracking inventory. Businesses can use a supply chain track-and-trace network to validate the quality and authenticity of an inventory component. Manufacturers and providers of equipment maintenance services can use such a network to maintain supplier performance, regulatory compliance and customer satisfaction. With customer satisfaction comes the potential for increased loyalty and cross-sales opportunities. Another application of an NRP solution is a gig platform for acquiring talent in large organizations. Current structures of how businesses find contingent labor are horribly imagined. There is no one source of truth regarding potential talent, and businesses do not really know the quality of a talent resource. However, a gig platform built on blockchain’s use of relational databases and distributed-ledger technology, would allow participants to track the performance and quality of individuals, show their availability or lack of availability and provide other huge benefits to both the individual and the companies that need their services. A third example is a payments and settlements network. This NRP solution would improve processes at banking and financial services companies and consequently also simplify the transaction experience for B2C and B2B customers. The enterprises could eliminate intermediaries (thus lowering cost) and create a real-time experience for customers. The trust among participants in the network also would assist in optimizing reconciliation, auditing and compliance. An overview of common benefits and goals attainable through from NRP solutions includes: Reduce process and turnaround time Reduce requirement for data entry time Reduce redundancies and inefficiencies in a process Reduce time to market Create new revenue streams through innovative solutions Create new market opportunities Because the network enables transparency and trust among participants or stakeholders, it also would support sharing real-time status updates (or audit processes). What could your company achieve as a participant in an interconnected super network that enables collaboration to create new avenues for revenue realization? I believe we will see exciting new opportunities as well as industry disruption from NRP solutions. The blockchain technology at the foundational base of an NRP solution will enable small players to participate in value creation where large players typically dominate a market. Furthermore, I believe we will see participants in collaborative network ecosystems create fundamentally different kinds of businesses – perhaps even a completely new industry. In my next few blog posts, I will share information on how to structure NRP solutions and how to govern such a “partnership of ecosystems.”
